image.altText: Former premier Mike Ahern

items.synopsis: Federal Nationals Leader David Littleproud says the party has lost one of its greats with the death of reformist premier Mike Ahern. He is being remembered as a man of great integrity.

title.children: 'A good and decent man': Former Queensland premier Mike Ahern dead at 81

image.altText: A man sits on a rock

items.synopsis: A coroner has stopped parents of Luke Gilbert from giving their family impact statement after they refused to edit sections deemed "factually incorrect and offensive" by police.

title.children: Police shooting victim's swastika tattoos analysed as parents barred from making 'offensive' impact statement

image.altText: a woman in pink and newborn baby

items.synopsis: Matthew Cox has been charged with murder after police found the bodies of his wife and baby girl.

title.children: Parents of Queensland man accused of killing his wife and 11-week-old daughter in 'state of shock'

image.altText: The Bushwalkers artwork showing a group of people outside.

items.synopsis: Southern Highlands baker Tracy Nickl was clearing out artwork from his grandfather's home when he nearly gave one worth more than a million dollars to an op shop until his friend, artist Ben Quilty, saw it.

title.children: Million-dollar painting that nearly ended up in op shop now bound for National Gallery

image.altText: Pauline Hanson, dressed in a red jacket, wears a serious expression as she walks out of the Senate.

items.synopsis: A misleading viral video shared by One Nation leader Pauline Hanson and anti-Voice campaigners has sparked a wave of racial abuse towards an Aboriginal family and has left another couple feeling "crucified".

title.children: Families distressed after 'highly misleading' video used by anti-Voice campaigners goes viral

image.altText: Ed Sheeran points at Michael Gudinski who hugs him and points a finger up. They wear matching black t shirts

items.synopsis: The star-studded Ego: The Michael Gudinski Story is loud, brash, and irreverent - just like the Mushroom mogul himself.

title.children: The Michael Gudinski doco is an irreverent portrait of the man who made the Australian music industry

image.altText: A sign indicating the way to the emergency apartment at a large, modern-looking hospital.

items.synopsis: A nurses' association says an ongoing failure to follow health procedures and policies at Townsville University Hospital has had disastrous consequences.

title.children: Nurses scared to work at Queensland hospital after deaths, sexual assault, association says

image.altText: Salma Paralluelo celebrates

items.synopsis: Spain beats Netherlands 2-1 after extra time to reach a first-ever FIFA Women's World Cup semifinal. Later, heavyweights Japan and Sweden meet at Eden Park in Auckland. Follow live.

title.children: Spain beat Netherlands to reach first-ever FIFA World Cup semifinal

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Spain are into the semifinals! And they have a new hero, their youngest ever World Cup goalscorer, Salma Paralluelo. Well, Spain deserved that on the balance of play, but the Netherlands did not make it easy for them. Aside from the penalty in the second half of normal time, they struggled to find a way through despite dominating possession. That is until Hermoso and Paralluelo combined for a delightful winner. The 2019 finalists are out, and Spain are into the final four for the first time ever.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: FULL-TIME: Spain 2 -1 Netherlands

children.content: (Getty)
Spain are into the semifinals!
And they have a new hero, their youngest ever World Cup goalscorer, Salma Paralluelo.
Well, Spain deserved that on the balance of play, but the Netherlands did not make it easy for them.
Aside from the penalty in the second half of normal time, they struggled to find a way through despite dominating possession.
That is until Hermoso and Paralluelo combined for a delightful winner.
The 2019 finalists are out, and Spain are into the final four for the first time ever.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Beautifully taken goal, she ran onto a flick through from Hermoso and took on Aniek Nouwen, cutting inside and out before slotting home with aplomb. It just snuck in off the post. The teenager has proven the hero here!
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 11' GOAAAAAAAAAAL SPAIN - IT'S PARALLUELO! 2-1 Spain

children.content: Beautifully taken goal, she ran onto a flick through from Hermoso and took on
Aniek Nouwen, cutting inside and out before slotting home with aplomb.
It just snuck in off the post.
The teenager has proven the hero here!
(Getty)
(Getty)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's a wonderful see-sawing match now. Spain largely the better side but the Netherlands look just as likely to land the killer blow. We're about 15 minutes away from penalties if nothing changes.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: HALF-TIME OF EXTRA TIME: Spain 1 - 1 Netherlands

children.content: It's a wonderful see-sawing match now. Spain largely the better side but the Netherlands look just as likely to land the killer blow.
We're about 15 minutes away from penalties if nothing changes.

image.altText: Emma Walters appears serious as she walks out of the Melbourne Magistrates' Court.

items.synopsis: Emma Walters had been charged with plotting to kill her former partner John Setka, but police have now dropped those and other serious charges. She still faces other charges.

title.children: Police drop serious charges against Emma Walters, wife of union boss John Setka

image.altText: Three Brisbane Broncos NRL players embrace as they celebrate a try.

items.synopsis: The Broncos, Sea Eagles, Rabbitohs and Roosters will travel to Las Vegas next year, as the NRL looks to showcase rugby league to the massive US market.

title.children: NRL names clubs for historic Las Vegas double-header in 2024

image.altText: Two women and a man wearing black flying suits hugging each other and smiling

items.synopsis: Virgin Galactic flew its commercial flight carrying tourists for the first time and reached 88 kilometres above Earth.

title.children: Caribbean mother-daughter duo and 80-year-old Olympian taken to the edge of space

image.altText: Dale Josiah sits on a hospital bed

items.synopsis: Dale Josiah and his family moved eight hours' drive from their community for vital health treatment. He's "overwhelmed" a new facility could see the family return home for good.

title.children: Dialysis keeps Dale alive, but his community makes life worth living. Soon, he could have both

image.altText: An Asian woman standing behind a coffee machine.

items.synopsis: Cafes and restaurants saw a boom of big-spending customers after the pandemic. Now, as cost-of-living pressures bite households and the cost of doing business grows, some in the hospitality industry are struggling to stay afloat.

title.children: A perfect storm is brewing at Lillian's cafe: Rising costs and fewer customers coming through the door

image.altText: A waitress in a white shirt carries a tray of glasses in a Canberra restaurant.

items.synopsis: To deal with the rising cost of living, there's nearly 194,000 young people juggling side hustles — the highest it's ever been — with some saying it's "unavoidable".

title.children: 'Young people are hustlers': Gen Z 'willing to do what they need to' to make ends meet

image.altText: Lowe gestures with one hand, sitting at a table in suit and tie, a news camera visible behind him.

items.synopsis: Philip Lowe has faced the house economics committee hearing as RBA governor for the final time. Meanwhile, US inflation continues to cool, increasing the chance the Federal Reserve will leave rates on hold at its next meeting. Follow live.

title.children: RBA boss says it's 'too early to declare victory' against inflation but 'the worst is over'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Philip Lowe was asked whether he had any thoughts about rent controls at the start of the hearing by committee chair Daniel Mulino. Mr Lowe replied by saying although they could provide short-term solutions to the problem, it would ultimately make the problem of a lack of affordable rentals worse. Here's his full response to that question: "When housing prices were rising quickly, people were saying, 'Well, we need to give people more money to help with them,' and when rents are rising quickly, 'We need to kind of cap the rent increases.' " They're short-term fixes that both of them, in my judgment, make the problem worse. "So what I would like to see is a longer-term focus on this because the short-term solutions, or the short-term responses, are not solutions, and generally giving people more money or capping prices doesn't help with the balance of supply and demand in the market. " In most cases, rent controls reduce incentive to add to supply, so it might help in the short run, it might relieve some pressure on people in the short run, and clearly that's the case, but we've got to keep the medium-term perspective on this. "Will that add to the supply of rental accommodation over time? My judgment would be that it would not and could actually reduce it. "It might help in the short run but create problems in the long run."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Would rent controls be an effective way to help manage with housing issues?

children.content: Philip Lowe was asked whether he had any thoughts about
rent controls
at the start of the hearing by committee chair Daniel Mulino.
Mr Lowe replied by saying although they could provide short-term solutions to the problem, it would ultimately make the problem of a lack of affordable rentals worse.
Here's his full response to that question:

"When housing prices were rising quickly, people were saying, 'Well, we need to give people more money to help with them,' and when rents are rising quickly, 'We need to kind of cap the rent increases.'
They're short-term fixes that both of them, in my judgment, make the problem worse
"So what I would like to see is a longer-term focus on this because the short-term solutions, or the short-term responses, are not solutions, and generally
giving people more money or capping prices doesn't help with the balance of supply and demand in the market
In most cases, rent controls reduce incentive to add to supply
, so it might help in the short run, it might relieve some pressure on people in the short run, and clearly that's the case, but we've got to keep the medium-term perspective on this.
"Will that add to the supply of rental accommodation over time?
My judgment would be that it would not and could actually reduce it.
"It might help in the short run but create problems in the long run."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There was a lot in that three-hour hearing — but one of the more interesting questions from earlier on was about potential solutions to the housing crisis. Philip Lowe was asked about a range of policies and measures to help with the housing crisis. "I keep coming back to the point that the solution lies in increasing supply, " he replied. "The rental vacancy rate at the moment is the lowest it's been in decades and some cities the lowest ever. "There's been strong demand for rental accommodation, and the rate of addition to the housing stock is slow. "This year, the population's increased by two and a half per cent. The number of dwellings in the country has increased by 1.5 per cent, so there's a big gap there, and when demand is strong and supply's weak, prices go up. "There's always a tendency to try and come up with short-term solutions, [but] there aren't short-term solutions here. "The solution has to be putting in place a structure that makes the supply side of the housing market more flexible, and that means zoning and planning deregulation and it means state and local governments being part of the solution." You can watch his full response below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'No short-term solutions' to housing crisis, Lowe says

children.content: There was a lot in that three-hour hearing — but one of the more interesting questions from earlier on was about potential solutions to the housing crisis.
Philip Lowe was asked about a range of policies and measures to help with the housing crisis.
"I keep coming back to the point that the
solution lies in increasing supply,
" he replied.
"The rental vacancy rate at the moment is the lowest it's been in decades and some cities the lowest ever.
"There's been strong demand for rental accommodation, and the rate of addition to the housing stock is slow.
"This year, the
population's increased by two and a half per cent
. The
number of dwellings in the country has increased by 1.5 per cent
, so there's a big gap there, and when demand is strong and supply's weak, prices go up.
"There's always a tendency to try and come up with short-term solutions, [but]
there aren't short-term solutions here.

"The solution has to be putting in place a structure that makes the supply side of the housing market more flexible, and that means zoning and planning deregulation and it means state and local governments being part of the solution."
You can watch his full response below:

mediaThumbnail.caption: Philip Lowe has told a House economics committee that policies such as rent freezes won't solve the housing crisis, and that an increase of supply is needed.

document.title: Outgoing RBA boss says 'no short-term solutions' to housing crisis

titleAlt.lg: Outgoing RBA boss says 'no short-term solutions' to housing crisis
titleAlt.md: Outgoing RBA boss says 'no short-term solutions' to housing crisis
titleAlt.sm: Outgoing RBA boss says 'no short-term solutions' to housing crisis

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We're nearing the end of the hearing and Philip Lowe has started to discuss his "popularity" (or lack thereof) depending on what's happening with the interest rate cycle. "We've raised interest rates in election campaigns, we've raised interest rates when it hasn't been popular with the political class," he said. "I hope that people understand that the decisions are taken completely independently. I've been involved in the interest rate setting process for a number of decades, and no politician has indirectly or directly put pressure on the bank during that period. "It's one of the very positive things about Australia — is that the political class do not put pressure on the central bank. And we take our decisions completely independently of the political noise. " I know what we do often is unpopular, and sometimes what I say is unpopular, but that hasn't diminished our resolve to do the right thing. "I hope Australians understand that." He continued discussing how being unpopular often comes with the territory of working at the RBA: "The reason that monetary policy has really been assigned to an independent central bank is it's very difficult for the political class to do what we're currently doing, that is putting up interest rates [and having] people hurting. "It's very uncomfortable, and we're putting up interest rates — that is incredibly unpopular. " I often read in the paper that I'm the most unpopular person in the country. That's fine. "That's why setting of interest rates and managing the inflation cycle has been assigned to an independent central bank, who doesn't have to worry about being liked and being popular. "
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Lowe acknowledges what he says can be 'unpopular'

children.content: We're nearing the end of the hearing and Philip Lowe has started to discuss his "popularity" (or lack thereof) depending on what's happening with the interest rate cycle.
"We've raised interest rates in election campaigns, we've raised interest rates when it hasn't been popular with the political class," he said.

"I hope that people understand that the decisions are taken completely independently. I've been involved in the interest rate setting process for a number of decades, and no politician has indirectly or directly put pressure on the bank during that period.
"It's one of the very positive things about Australia — is that the political class do not put pressure on the central bank. And we take our decisions completely independently of the political noise.
I know what we do often is unpopular, and sometimes what I say is unpopular, but that hasn't diminished our resolve to do the right thing
"I hope Australians understand that."
He continued discussing how being unpopular often comes with the territory of working at the RBA:

"The reason that monetary policy has really been assigned to an independent central bank is it's very difficult for the political class to do what we're currently doing, that is putting up interest rates [and having] people hurting.
"It's very uncomfortable, and we're putting up interest rates — that is incredibly unpopular.
I often read in the paper that I'm the most unpopular person in the country. That's fine.
"That's why setting of interest rates and managing the inflation cycle has been assigned to an independent central bank, who doesn't have to worry about being liked and being popular. "

image.altText: an aboriginal man wearing a cap carrying an orange painting

items.synopsis: As Darwin launches one of Australia's biggest Indigenous art fairs, some artists fear allegations about interference in Indigenous paintings may have tarnished the industry's reputation and affected sales.

title.children: Indigenous artists fear reputational damage in wake of interference allegations

image.altText: A burning building next to palm trees blowing in strong wind

items.synopsis: Experts say a combination of factors have led to wildfires in Hawaii claiming 53 lives, putting it in the top 10 deadliest fires in the 21st century globally and the worst in Hawaii's history.

title.children: How a drought, a heatwave and a hurricane created Hawaii's deadliest wildfires ever

image.altText: A small brown and white dog standing on a rocky foreshore, with water visible in the background

items.synopsis: Pet owners are urged to take precautions against wild dog attacks in the Whitsunday region, as one family still grieves the loss of their beloved Cavalier King Charles Spaniel-cross and calls for more to be done.

title.children: Family's heartbreak over wild dog attack as concerns grow over increasing pest population

image.altText: Nicolas Cage on the red carpet.

items.synopsis: High school students in WA's South West are "pumped" about a chance to star alongside a Hollywood heavyweight when shooting starts in their surfing towns.

title.children: Nicolas Cage movie rumours spark teen stardom dreams in renowned Aussie surf spots

image.altText: Only fences or retaining walls stand among the blocks of charred rubble.

items.synopsis: The death toll from a fire disaster on the Hawaiian island of Maui could surge "significantly" higher than 60, the state's governor says.

title.children: Hawaiian fire death toll jumps to 53, thousands homeless in Maui town of Lahaina

image.altText: A family carrying luggage walks out the doors of an airport terminal

items.synopsis: The federal government will raise the number of places in Australia's humanitarian visa program to 20,000 from its previous cap of 17,875. The move returns the cap to the level set by Labor when it was last in power.

title.children: Government lifts humanitarian intake cap to 20,000 visas

image.altText: A close up image of an engineered bacteria.

items.synopsis: The engineered bacteria called Acinetobacter baylyi has the ability to search through an environment, like the colon, and detect cancer DNA. Researchers say it could be used to screen for bowel cancer in a blood test.

title.children: Researchers engineer bacteria that could detect bowel cancer without stool test

image.altText: A husband and wife clutching a letter outside a home.

items.synopsis: Brisbane City Council says it's sorry for sending cryptic letters that led home owners to mistakenly believe their houses would be bulldozed to make way for parks.

title.children: Brisbane council apologises after 'ambiguous' letters leave home owners fearing they will be forced to sell

image.altText: Debbie Kilroy stands at the door of an office.

items.synopsis: Crusading lawyer Debbie Kilroy from Sisters Inside says it's "horrific" a woman on bail had to ask a Queensland court to send her back to jail, after she couldn't find suitable housing.

title.children: Prison 'the only place that can't say no' for women on bail without a home, advocate says

image.altText: Jacinta Price is on the left speaking in the red Senate chamber. On the right is Anthony Albanese speaking in the green house

items.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and Shadow Minister for Indigenous Australians Jacinta Price have been arguing about the length of the Uluru Statement from the Heart. Who is correct?

title.children: CheckMate: Anthony Albanese says the Uluru Statement is one page, Jacinta Price says it's 26. Who is correct?

image.altText: Donald Trump (left) in a white shirt and black jacket. A blonde smiling woman (right) wearing sunglasses and brown jacket.

items.synopsis: Former US president Donald Trump launches an appeal against a judge's dismissal of his claim that writer E. Jean Carroll defamed him by accusing him of rape.

title.children: Trump appeals against judge's dismissal of defamation claim against E. Jean Carroll

image.altText: An island-like complex with red buildings and trees surrounded by water is seen from above, a white strip connecting to land

items.synopsis: The city of Bangkok is sinking, with coastal residents rebuilding their homes on stilts and erecting giant walls to protect sacred buildings from being swallowed by the sea.

title.children: 'This not fortune-telling, this is science': Climate change experts sound the alarm on the sinking city of Bangkok

image.altText: Margot winks as the camera as she claps in the air while wearing a gold glittery jumpsuit.

items.synopsis: Kuwait bans the blockbuster film, with Lebanon poised to do the same, saying the film contradicts religious values.

title.children: Barbie faces bans in the Middle East for 'promoting homosexuality'

image.altText: Tupac Shakur

items.synopsis: Police body-worn video emerges of the moment a couple was detained in connection with Tupac Shakur's cold case murder.

title.children: Tupac Shakur cold case investigators release footage of raid outside Las Vegas

image.altText: A crocodile basks in a patch of sun on a creek bed.

items.synopsis: The soldiers suffered broken bones and other injuries when they were attacked while swimming in a Queensland waterway in 2021.

title.children: Defence charged over crocodile attack on two soldiers

image.altText: A black and white bird on the left, and a white bird with brown wings and blue touches on the right

items.synopsis: It's time to vote again as our quest to find Australia's favourite animal sound reaches a crescendo. Is your favourite among the top 10, and will it win the race for the nation's hearts and ears?

title.children: The nation has chosen its top 10 animal sounds. Vote now to keep your favourite in the race

image.altText: A Pacific Islander worker picking raspberries.

items.synopsis: Changes to the Pacific Islander labour scheme mean workers must be guaranteed a minimum of 30 hours of work each week, but the horticulture industry says the seasonal nature of the work and weather events make that unworkable.

title.children: Growers warn 'unworkable' Pacific Islander worker changes lack critical flexibility required for horticulture
